--- Manage Variation ---

Variation occurs in all natural processes and if not managed, can cause undesireable effects. Statistical methods are available to understand the types and amount of variation that occurs. Common Cause variation is the variation naturally seen from the processes being used. Special Cause variation is variation caused by some unusual factor that can generally be controlled and eliminated. Control Charts are a common tool for keeping processes within their design limits.

A good summary of control charts can be found here

Key statistic concepts and terminology that are important for correctly to the practice of Robust Engineering.

Inferential Statistics

When we “infer” characteristics of the entire population based on characteristics of a sampling of the population. Since it is impractical to test entire populations, we will be infering characteristics measured in a limited sampling to the entire population. In plain english, we test a sampling of parts to determine how all parts will behave.

Central Tendancy
Mean
average value for a normally distributed set of data.
Median
middle value for non-normally distributed set of data.
Mode
most often occuring value for attribute data.
Variability
Range
distance between exreme values (Maximum - Minimum)
Variance (σ2)
the Average Squared Deviation of each data point from the Mean
Standard Deviation (σ)
the Square Root of the Variance

Range is most sensitive to outliers. σ has same units as the data so is more intuitive. σ2 can be averaged so is a good metric for dealing with multiple datasets.
